Situation1: Laundry needs to be done so clean clothes are available for the family’s activities.
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: They are the only volunteer assigned to unlock the facility and begin the service for people already waiting outside.
Story: I glanced at the clock, heart pounding. The laundry basket overflowed, and my spouse had reminded me twice this morning that the kids needed clean uniforms for tomorrow’s soccer game. I’d promised to help, to share the load, to be present at home. But my phone buzzed with a reminder: my volunteer shift started in twenty minutes. I was the only one scheduled to open the community center today, and I knew people would already be waiting outside, counting on me to unlock the doors and start the breakfast service. I could picture their faces—some of them elderly, some with children in tow—hoping for a warm meal. My mind raced, torn between the pile of laundry and the faces at the center. Both needed me, both expected me to show up. I stood frozen in the hallway, keys in one hand, laundry detergent in the other, feeling the weight of letting someone down no matter what I chose.
